--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> First, generation champions are quite different from
> *dominant solutions*.  

Ah...okay.  I'd skimmed over the fact that you were
using a Dominance Tournament approach.

> Bearing this in mind, the average complexity of
> random fitness runs
> tells us nothing, because we have no interest in
> what the average
> complexity of something that is *not* strictly
> better would be.  All
> that would show is that when fitness does not
> improve, average
> complexity goes up.  

Yes.  That's what I thought the point of comparing a
fitness-based run to a random-fitness run was all
about.

> But the whole point of this
> experiment is what
> could happen when strategies *do* strictly improve.
> 
> So we want to know, does complexity *have* to go up
> when dominance goes up?  That's the question; is it
> inevitable that complexity would
> go up in NEAT?  

These still seem like two different questions to me.

And again, the answer the first question seems, in
general, to be no.  Your fixed-topology experiment
alone demonstrates this.  No complexification at all
is necessary for fitness to improve, so complexity
doesn't have to go up when dominance goes up.

And the answer to the second question still seems to
be yes. The max complexity, the average complexity,
and even the minimum complexity all increase in a
random population.  The min complexity doesn't
increase very much, but there's still complexification
going on. 

> The random fitness
> runs show that indeed NEAT does keep around simple
> solutions.  

Maybe it is still a quibble over semantics, but I
wouldn't refer to any individual in a random run as a
"solution".  Simple architectures persist in a random
run, alongside other species that are growing
increasingly complex.

This allows NEAT to retain a broad spectrum of
*potential* solutions if and when a fitness function
is applied, but I'm not sure that range is really any
different whether or not selection pressure is being
applied to the population.

That's essentially where I think there's a mismatch. 
I understood your paper to be asserting that the
dynamics of a fitness-based run and a random-fitness
run were fundamentally different.  But I don't think
they are...and the data as presented doesn't seem to
give enough information to draw that conclusion.

> Yes that's why they persist.  That's the whole
> point.
> NEAT keeps the simple stuff around as long as it
> isn't
> doing significantly worse.  

Well, it keeps simple architectures around whether or
not they're being judged at all.  In a random run it's
not a matter of doing "better" or "worse", since there
is no standard of measurement.

> The point is certainly not that fitness cannot
> increase when
> topologies are kept static.  Rather, the point is
> that when
> topologies can complexify, that complexification is
> used to
> advantage.  In other words, the system uses
> increases in 
> complexity to increase fitness even though it
> doesn't have to.

The system is good at exploiting complexity, leading
to proportionally better fitness gains than a
fixed-topology run.  This makes sense...I thought
before that you might have been asserting that
complexity was necessary for an increase in fitness in
this domain.  If so, I misunderstood.

> Yes, agreed.  What we are trying to say is that
> increasing 
> complexity helped increase dominance in this domain.

Proportionally more than fixed-topology or
simplification-alone techniques, right?

> Yes of course, I agree.  But what I mean to say is
> that
> in a lot of domains, the best solutions are complex.
>  So
> we need some way of getting there.

Right...I agree.  All I've asserted all along is that
if solutions become more complex than necessary, it
may be a good idea to have a way of scaling back that
complexity.

> I never meant to imply anything like that.   That is
> a blanket statement.  Most increases in complexity
> actually
> decrease fitness.  However, note that every high
> dimensional
> space has a global optimum at least as high if not
> higher
> than that of any subspace it completely contains.  
> In other words, theoretically, you can only win by
> adding 
> dimensions.  Of course that does not mean you
> *should* always
> do so...what you should do is only add them if you
> need to.
> But in really tough domains, it's clear that it will
> be
> necessary to complexify to some extent.

Okay...then we really aren't far apart in our
thinking. :)

> Your counterexamples beg the question, do you mean
> to imply that a system that cannot complexify would 
> display a better arms race?  

No, certainly not.  I think incremental
complexification, as you've demonstrated, is more
effective than systems that do not allow
complexification or that start with high random
complexity and prune.  I'm not disputing that.

> If that is not your
> implication,
> what is your counterexample meant to imply?  

I mean to imply that in an arms race, populations with
simplification in their toolbox (along with
complexification) would probably have a distinct
advantage over populations that can only complexify.

Let's say two hypothetical species, predator and prey,
have developed highly sophisticated behavioral
patterns when confronting one another.  The prey has
evolved all sorts of evasion heuristics, along with
accompanying physical attributes, to try to escape the
predator.  The predator has tried to keep up with the
arms race by evolving its own set of tracking
heuristics.

Now let's say the environment has convenient hiding
places.  A predator that simply hunkers down in the
shadows and waits for one of the prey to walk by can
easily snatch them up for a meal.

In fact, this is very much like the evolved behavior
of one of your dominant bot strategies, isn't it?  The
bot waits until it's opponent scurries around and
depletes a lot of its energy, then pounces at the last
minute.

You describe this strategy as more sophisticated than
one which actively seeks out food throughout the
environment, but this estimation seems subjective.

Which strategy really is more complex, behaviorally?

Could the "wait-and-pounce" heuristic be represented
by a much less complex network?  Can you conclusively
say one way or the other?

One of your best solutions has over 200 connections
and 11 hidden nodes.  Could the same behavior be
represented by a much less complex network?  How do
you know that all of that complexity is necessary?

What I'm suggesting is that, NEAT's approach is to
incrementally add complexity across a broad range of
architectures, and it keeps simple designs around as
other potential starting points.  But in some cases,
it may be more beneficial for the dominant strategies
to simplify.

A marine animal that evolves from an active predator
to one that hides in a coral nook needs very simple
heuristics to catch prey--if one appears in front of
my nook, snap and grab.  This behavior is much less
complex than an active predator who has to swim around
looking for prey, trying to distinguish them from all
sorts of background noise, and then once finding them
having to chase them down, zigging and zagging after
them.  And this has happened in nature.  Complex
behavior has given way to the evolution of less
complex behavior...because it made the species more
fit.

My view is that simplification is probably an
extremely effective tool in most arms races.  In
situations where both sides have developed elaborate
interactions, an individual strategy that is more
simple and direct may be much more effective.

> Very good discussion- I agree these are important
> issues to think
> about.  I apologize for my perhaps overzealous
> defense of our
> analysis- I feel it is actually good practice for me
> to try to respond
> to these kind of questions, especially considering I
> will eventually
> have interviews where similar arguments may come up.

Sure...healthy, direct discussions are a good thing.
:)

I think you had mentioned that the addition of the
simplification-only experiment was at the request of
one of the paper's reviewers.  Is that right?  Was
this second paper reviewed again, by the same
reviewers as the first?  What kind of feedback did you
receive?  I'm just wanting a bit of insight into the
process.

Derek
